Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2016 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Michael Tait is "Extremal Graph Theory and Combinatorial Number Theory." The host institution for the fellowship is Carnegie Mellon University, and the sponsoring scientist is Po-Shen Loh.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was focused on extremal graph theory and combinatorial number theory. Questions in extremal graph theory ask to quantify when one can find structure in a network, and questions in combinatorial number theory ask to find structure in sets of (for example) integers knowing only how dense the set is. The project made significant progress in both of these areas as well as related areas including spectral graph theory (where one uses a matrix to understand a network) and Ramsey theory.

 

The main intellectual merit of the project comes from the 18 publications that were produced during the grant. Several of these publications were accepted to top combinatorics journals. Furthermore, several of the publications solved long-standing open problems (one example: a conjecture of Aldous and Fill from 1994 asking for which graph a random walk "mixes slowest"). Additional merit comes from the interplay between different mathematical areas in the research. The research made contributions and opened future lines of work in several areas including extremal graph theory, combinatorial number theory, spectral graph theory, design theory, and finite geometry.

 

The broader impacts of the project stem mainly from advisement of undergraduates. The PI supervied 6 undergraduate reearch projects during the grant, resulting in 5 publications. Several of these undergraduates presented their work in either talks or poster sessions. Furthermore, the PI served on panels to give advice to both undergraduate and graduate students. Additionally, the PI disseminated his work by giving 45 talks during the grant. Finally, the PI organized an AMS session, a minisymposium at the SIAM Discrete Math meeting, and a one-day conference for Women in Mathematics at Carnegie Mellon designed to build a network for young women working in mathematics.
